segment.source: Deploy and test a user-mode test application in MMOS
segment.target: Deploy and test a user-mode test application in MMOS

segment.source: Deploy and test a user-mode test application in MMOS
segment.target: Deploy and test a user-mode test application in MMOS

segment.source: Deploy and test a user-mode test application in MMOS
segment.target: Deploy and test a user-mode test application in MMOS

segment.source: To copy files to an MMOS image and run programs, you can use FTP and Telnet over a Virtual Ethernet connection.
segment.target: To copy files to an MMOS image and run programs, you can use FTP and Telnet over a Virtual Ethernet connection.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: The USB drivers and protocols described here must not be used in manufacturing or retail servicing.
segment.target: The USB drivers and protocols described here must not be used in manufacturing or retail servicing.

segment.source: They are provided as a convenience for engineering bring-up.
segment.target: They are provided as a convenience for engineering bring-up.

segment.source: Preparing the device
segment.target: Preparing the device

segment.source: Engineering builds of the OS typically include Ping, FTP, and Telnet servers.
segment.target: Engineering builds of the OS typically include Ping, FTP, and Telnet servers.

segment.source: To confirm that these are active in the OS, examine the startup configuration or establish a debug connection to MMOS to view the files that are loaded.
segment.target: To confirm that these are active in the OS, examine the startup configuration or establish a debug connection to MMOS to view the files that are loaded.

segment.source: To configure a device to support TCP/IP over USB, you must install the necessary tools and use the BCDEdit tool to modify the device’s boot options that are stored in the BCD file.
segment.target: To configure a device to support TCP/IP over USB, you must install the necessary tools and use the BCDEdit tool to modify the device’s boot options that are stored in the BCD file.

segment.source: Running Virtual Ethernet and determining the IP address of the device
segment.target: Running Virtual Ethernet and determining the IP address of the device

segment.source: Virtual Ethernet creates a connection between the device's USB connection and the TCP/IP transport on the PC.
segment.target: Virtual Ethernet creates a connection between the device's USB connection and the TCP/IP transport on the PC.

segment.source: connecting the device or powering it on, start Virtual Ethernet on the PC.
segment.target: connecting the device or powering it on, start Virtual Ethernet on the PC.

segment.source: VirtEth.exe is located in the “%ProgramFiles(x86)%Microsoft Windows Phone 8 KDBG Connectivitybin” folder.
segment.target: VirtEth.exe is located in the “%ProgramFiles(x86)%Microsoft Windows Phone 8 KDBG Connectivitybin” folder.

segment.source: A Virtual Ethernet console window will open.
segment.target: A Virtual Ethernet console window will open.

segment.source: Leave this window open to maintain the connection to the phone; closing the window closes the connection.
segment.target: Leave this window open to maintain the connection to the phone; closing the window closes the connection.

segment.source: With Virtual Ethernet running, connect and power on the phone.
segment.target: With Virtual Ethernet running, connect and power on the phone.

segment.source: When the device is connected, you will see lines of output that include the MAC address of the device.
segment.target: When the device is connected, you will see lines of output that include the MAC address of the device.

segment.source: Virtual Ethernet reports the device’s MAC address in output similar to the following:
segment.target: Virtual Ethernet reports the device’s MAC address in output similar to the following:

segment.source: Note the 12-digit device MAC address from the VirtEth console window and use it in the next step to determine the device's TCP/IP address.
segment.target: Note the 12-digit device MAC address from the VirtEth console window and use it in the next step to determine the device's TCP/IP address.

segment.source: Open a new command-prompt window and type arp -a.
segment.target: Open a new command-prompt window and type arp -a.

segment.source: Output similar to the following will be displayed.
segment.target: Output similar to the following will be displayed.

segment.source: Use the IP address that is associated with the device MAC address to connect to the device via FTP and Telnet.
segment.target: Use the IP address that is associated with the device MAC address to connect to the device via FTP and Telnet.

segment.source: Establishing an FTP connection
segment.target: Establishing an FTP connection

segment.source: To browse and copy files via FTP:
segment.target: To browse and copy files via FTP:

segment.source: Open Windows Explorer and type: FTP:W.X.Y.Z in the address bar, replacing W.X.Y.Z with the IP address of the device.
segment.target: Open Windows Explorer and type: FTP:W.X.Y.Z in the address bar, replacing W.X.Y.Z with the IP address of the device.

segment.source: You should see the files on the device listed.
segment.target: You should see the files on the device listed.

segment.source: Use Windows Explorer to copy files to or from the device, such as executable test programs or logs of test results.
segment.target: Use Windows Explorer to copy files to or from the device, such as executable test programs or logs of test results.

segment.source: To close the FTP connection, unmount the phone file system by selecting Safely Remove Hardware in the Windows notification area.
segment.target: To close the FTP connection, unmount the phone file system by selecting Safely Remove Hardware in the Windows notification area.

segment.source: Establishing a Telnet session
segment.target: Establishing a Telnet session

segment.source: Make sure Telnet is enabled on the PC.
segment.target: Make sure Telnet is enabled on the PC.

segment.source: To enable Telnet in the Windows operating system, select Control PanelPrograms and FeaturesTurn Windows features on or off.
segment.target: To enable Telnet in the Windows operating system, select Control PanelPrograms and FeaturesTurn Windows features on or off.

segment.source: In the Windows Features list, select Telnet Client, and then click OK.
segment.target: In the Windows Features list, select Telnet Client, and then click OK.

segment.source: To establish a Telnet session with the device:
segment.target: To establish a Telnet session with the device:

segment.source: Open a command-prompt window and type: telnetW.X.Y.Z, replacing W.X.Y.Z with the IP address of the device
segment.target: Open a command-prompt window and type: telnetW.X.Y.Z, replacing W.X.Y.Z with the IP address of the device

segment.source: The command prompt window that appears is cmd.exe running on the device.
segment.target: The command prompt window that appears is cmd.exe running on the device.

segment.source: From that command prompt, you can run commands on the device, such as executing test applications that you included in the MMOS image.
segment.target: From that command prompt, you can run commands on the device, such as executing test applications that you included in the MMOS image.

segment.source: Troubleshooting: Confirming TCP/IP connectivity
segment.target: Troubleshooting: Confirming TCP/IP connectivity

segment.source: You can use ping to test the TCP/IP connection with the device:
segment.target: You can use ping to test the TCP/IP connection with the device:

segment.source: Open a command-prompt window and type: pingW.X.Y.Z, replacing W.X.Y.Z with the IP address of the device
segment.target: Open a command-prompt window and type: pingW.X.Y.Z, replacing W.X.Y.Z with the IP address of the device

segment.source: The command should indicate that the packets were returned.
segment.target: The command should indicate that the packets were returned.

segment.source: If this does not work, one common issue to investigate is the firewall configuration on the PC.
segment.target: If this does not work, one common issue to investigate is the firewall configuration on the PC.

segment.source: Debugging in MMOS
segment.target: Debugging in MMOS

segment.source: To enable debugger support in MMOS, both communication and OS settings must be modified.
segment.target: To enable debugger support in MMOS, both communication and OS settings must be modified.

segment.source: Enabling debug support
segment.target: Enabling debug support

segment.source: To enable debugging support in MMOS, specify the following internal optional feature in the MfgOEMInput.xml file.
segment.target: To enable debugging support in MMOS, specify the following internal optional feature in the MfgOEMInput.xml file.

segment.source: This adds the required packages to the MMOS image.
segment.target: This adds the required packages to the MMOS image.

segment.source: For more info about working with the MfgOEMInput.xml file, see MMOS image definition.
segment.target: For more info about working with the MfgOEMInput.xml file, see MMOS image definition.

segment.source: Enabling communication settings
segment.target: Enabling communication settings

segment.source: To enable the OS, communication settings must be changed after the image is flashed.
segment.target: To enable the OS, communication settings must be changed after the image is flashed.

segment.source: Establishing the debug connection
segment.target: Establishing the debug connection

segment.source: To connect to MMOS for debugging, use WinDbg to specify the key and port that you configured earlier by using BCDEdit.
segment.target: To connect to MMOS for debugging, use WinDbg to specify the key and port that you configured earlier by using BCDEdit.
